posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28153120
Not everything in a relationship can be assigned a label that has x value like in a videogame, and that way of thinking, of reducing everything to easy to read terms, can be very unhelpful.

The facts are that she is dating you, that she chose to date you, meaning that to her, overall, you are pretty much an equal, or at least you’re at a level which she considers good enough for bf material. She likes you for who you are, the chemistry of a couple can’t be explained in 1-10 scores. I recently broke off a relationship with an objective 9/10 and now am attracted to someone who objectively is much lower than that (to me she’s 10/10)

You can’t convince yourself of that, but why would she cheat on you? Since she liked you to begin with, and provided that things haven’t changed much, there shouldn’t be any reason for her to cheat unless: you change into someone she dislikes or she starts wanting you to change into someone better and you don’t. Just keep a lookout for these two things and most importantly: don’t be insecure, it’s a really big turnoff to ask someone if they’d cheat on you, and puts the ideia in their head. Also if you’re insecure it sends the message that you feel inferior to her, and she might start thinking that you actually are.

Also, your feelings of being unworthy are probably general and not caused by the relationship, just manifested by this specific scenario. I’m not saying you should go to therapy, but you should do some introspection about why you feel this way overall. Maybe work on some aspects of your life that would boost your confidence, like getting a job, going to the gym or whatever.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>28151312
She's shy and probably has doubts about herself and being good enough for you. She likely waited a month because she wasn't sure of herself or if she should contact you back. Do your best to make her feel comfortable around you. Getting a better image about yourself will do wonders for that.

I'm also a shy person and sometimes only check my phone every other day. She's moving, that would definitely contribute to her lack of responses. If I was moving, I would cancel most or all social plans until I was done. Long response times usually has to do with being busy with something else in that moment and not remember to text back on the first free moment, or not having heard the notification for your message, or having heard it but then getting distracted. If she's read your text, she might be too busy in that moment to think of a response. It's not like she's ignoring you entirely, she still responds the next day and is asking you out. She's interested.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
It's important to consider your interests and strengths when deciding whether to continue pursuing a computer science degree. Computer science is a broad field that encompasses many different areas, and not all of them may be a good fit for you.

While a strong foundation in math is important for some areas of computer science, such as algorithms and theoretical computer science, there are also many areas that are less math-intensive, such as computer systems, human-computer interaction, and software engineering. If you enjoy coding and digital system building, these might be areas to consider exploring.

It's also important to remember that even if math isn't your strongest subject, you may still be able to succeed in a computer science program if you are willing to put in the extra effort to master the material.

Additionally, there are many other fields and industries that you can use your skills in, such as software development, IT, Cybersecurity, AI, and machine learning. If you're not interested in math but good at coding and digital system building, you may still find a lot of opportunities to apply your skills and find success in the field.

It's important to research the curriculum of the computer science program you're considering and speak with professors or current students to get a better sense of how much math is involved. You can also speak with professionals in the field and get their perspective on the importance of math in computer science, and whether it would be a good fit for you.

Ultimately, the decision is yours. If you're not really into math but good at coding and digital system building, you might want to consider exploring other areas of computer science or related fields that align more with your interests and strengths.

Dad was arrested when I was 10. My mom was abusive before, but the stress of becoming the sole provider ramped that shit up.
I learned some masculine things from the few men in my life -- neighbors taught me how to mow lawns, bring down trees, do some very minor craft work, while my uncle taught me to shave. But they were never people to aspire to be.
I struggled to want to embrace the good parts of my dad, even considering going into the same career field as him, but his really bad shit came to light right around the time I discovered my true passions and started to pursue them.
But this thread is about moms, so I'll pivot to that.
Despite all the abuse -- the actual gaslighting, the emotional manipulation, and the occasional hitting -- I was still the favorite child in the home. My sisters lament about how much easier I had it than them. One of my sister's has a scar across her chest from my mom scraping a lipstick tube against her after catching her with a Chuck Palahniuk book and calling her a disgusting whore.
My physical abuse ended right around the time I was 14 and officially became taller than my mom. The emotional shit was still there, though. I was highly risk averse, living essentially multiple lives between school, my friends, my sisters, my mom, and my grandma (she would watch us while my mom worked toward a masters degree while I was in high school). I did what I could to hide everything bad about myself, which made the really bad shit that inevitably occurred stand out dramatically.
I was scared of females, under the impression that my mom would judge harshly anyone I attempted to date. I later found out that wasn't the case, but when a girl sent me a bikini pic I completely panicked thinking any and all potential porn use as a minor would get my mom fired from her job and render us homeless (yes, this is what she told me when she saw porn in the browser history once).
1/?

While in high school, I realized how mediocre a cook my mom was. In hindsight, it was that she was too fucking busy with work, her school, 3 kids, and trying to work with attorneys to get my dad out of prison, but it made it that available food in the house was uncommon outside of dinners. I learned to cook so I could be able to eat more than the shitty cafeteria meals at lunch and the frozen, processed meals that awaited me for dinner. However, this was always a delicate practice because I was only guessing at what raw food was "planned" for meals, and my attempts to feed myself got me in trouble a number of times.
As implied with my "multiple lives" statement, I became quite good at lying convincingly and garnering pity from people. My mom never bought it, but peers, teachers, and others near me would never pay it a second thought if I was truthful.
I think one of the biggest ironies is that while it was a horrible, abusive situation, I have only recently been breaking the dependence on my mom for my life (I'm in my 30s). I relied on her for so fucking much in my 20s, when I truly shouldn't have. She was not a good advisor for school/work situations, she was far from a good confidant for my romantic life, and frankly even visits had some strange sense of tension and obligation, particularly around holidays.
I'm kind of rambling now, but it's really hard to say which was more impactful -- the abuse or the lack of masculine upbringing. My sisters claim I had it easier, but they're both married with children and I've never had much self confidence and ability to be vulnerable with people. They've taken great risks in their lives, and I'm the one who barely survived a suicide attempt.
I might can articulate specific issues better, but I think this incoherent mess should suffice for now.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>28147864
Untrue. My mother was an accomplished attorney who ran her own law firm, and she was the daughter of a highly educated upper-middle class couple. She loved myself and my sister very dearly, and always did all she could to make sure we were provided and cared for, and tried her best to make us feel loved. Sitting here now, I think I can genuinely say she did all in her power to be as best a mother she could possibly be, and I both love and appreciate her for her efforts.

However, that she had to do everything by herself definitely severely impacted her ability to be present for our upbringing. All of that responsibility left her drained and frequently emotionally unavailable, and her constant stress rubbed off on both myself and my sister. I definitely inherited most of my anxiety from her, and my sister, who was a highly energetic, loud, and rebellious child, came to resent my mother because she felt like she never wanted to spend time or energy on her.

This lessened as we got older, since my mother eventually got her business sorted so that she had more available free time to spend with us, but the impression that our mother was unavailable, or even absent to some degree during our early childhood, has I think played a big roll in informing how my sister and I have gone on to develop as people.

With all that said, I still love my mom, and thanks to her efforts and the efforts of my other relatives, I'm at least a functional human being who can go outside in normal society, which is more than can be said for many young men raised by single mothers, so I think she did alright.

posts.com:
Confidence can come from a variety of sources and can be influenced by many factors. Making a girlfriend is not a requirement for developing confidence, and confidence is not a requirement for making a girlfriend.

Having a romantic partner can certainly boost one's confidence and self-esteem, but it is not the only way to gain confidence. Confidence can also come from achieving personal goals, overcoming challenges, developing new skills, and building positive relationships with friends and family.

It's worth noting that confidence can fluctuate and can be affected by life events, so it's important to work on building and maintaining confidence through a variety of means.

Ultimately, confidence is a personal journey and it's important to focus on building self-confidence, self-esteem and self-love. The more you like and accept yourself, the more likely you are to attract the right person in your life.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28136719
>I don't feel I have anything left to find meaning in.
I've found finding meaning to be completely meaningless. In my case, I became completely obsessed with raw pragmatism. I could sit around navel gazing about "What's my meaning here on this Earth?" or think about stuff like, "It's too fucking cold in this house, what can I do about that?" The latter is more urgent and important, so it wins out. The problem with "finding meaning" is that although it'simportant, it's also really, really not-urgent--it's also not _that_ important because you can live your life without it. There's a weird philosophical asymmetry in it.
>morbidly depressed
What's your cope? Loads of dark humor? I kind of like depressed people, they're always really honest and are pretty funny.
>friendless
Got any family?
>balding
I wonder if the same is happening to me. I'm 36, you?
In any case, I wouldn't worry about it. I don't meet that many who really care. If anything, balding men have this superpower of not being the object of suspicion so much.
>incel
Do you _really_ want to have sex in our current time? Idk, I don't know anything about having sex myself. I never really got the attraction.

When I was very young, I enjoyed biking, sports, and video games, all of which have lost a lot of appeal--can't do anything very physical for too long due to my condition anyway.

The only thing I can think of that's important to me both then and now is companionship.

>>28142973
>So how is it going anon?
Thanks for introducing this topic. Things are very difficult however.
I spend virtually every moment of my life paralyzed by both physical pain and loneliness. The loneliness is worse, that alone is enough to make me feel like I'm dying.
It's certainly an interesting observation that people with NDEs are so likely to develop a belief in an afterlife, but I don't find this testimony to completely fool proof. I will ponder on it more though.
> we are eternal and will go to heaven unconditionally when we die and that the meaning of life is to learn to love and be kind and thrive here despite how hard it is in this world.
I want to love and be loved more than anything. Given both my circumstances and my condition, I feel my ability to do so has been literally crippled. If I were to believe that an afterlife of happiness is confirmed to be awaiting me after death, then I'd pursue it in a heartbeat. It feels like this probably isn't your intention though.
A number of my doctors have given up on me. I guess I'll cross that bridge once all of them do.

>>28151283
It's difficult to know myself sometimes.
Part of it is that, as distant as my family is, the thought of causing them grief pains me. Another part of it is an instinctual fear of death. I think another part is wanting to leave some positive mark on the world before I go.
I've honestly struggled with suicidal thinking for most of my life, but the closer I get the more severe some of these reservations become--not sure how commonplace that is.
>>28151301
I recognize that probably for everyone unhappy with their lives, it's likely due to varying combinations of being dealt a bad hand and also fucking up/being a retard. I understand that at the end of the day, no one can be held accountable for your happiness but yourself, and there are certainly retard-moments I had in the past where I could have done things differently that I'm kicking myself for.
Admittedly I've never exactly been overflowing with confidence, but a big part of my feelings of hopelessness at this moment also have to do with the complications that my spinal degeneration is causing me, and how many options for self-improvement and socializing it's taken off the table.
I probably average about 2 hours of sleep a night due to being in constant pain, and I spend a lot of time in a hazy fatigue, so I feel that would make me kind of miserable regardless. However, you're correct in that there are things I likely COULD be doing to try and derive more meaning from my life. I'm just at a point where I've having immense difficulty conceiving of how anything I'd realistically be able to achieve would be worth this amount of indefinite suffering.

It sounds like you're feeling frustrated and upset with your boyfriend's communication style and his inability to express himself clearly. This can be a challenging issue in any relationship, and it's important to find a way to communicate effectively.

It's important to remember that everyone has their own unique way of communicating and expressing themselves. It's possible that your boyfriend may have difficulty articulating his thoughts and feelings, and may not know how to respond when confronted with difficult or uncomfortable situations.

It's also important to remember that everyone makes mistakes and it's normal to have conflicts in a relationship. It's important to approach these conflicts with an open mind and a willingness to listen and understand your partner's perspective.

It's important to have an open and honest conversation with your boyfriend about how his communication style affects your relationship. Try to express your feelings in a clear and respectful way and ask him to do the same. Encourage him to be honest and open with you, and let him know that you're there to listen and support him.

It's also important to consider seeking help from a couples therapist or counselor who can help you and your boyfriend to work through communication issues and improve your relationship.

It's important to remember that building trust takes time and effort. Be patient and understanding with your boyfriend, and remember that relationships take work. If you are feeling mistreated, unheard or unloved, it's important to communicate that to your boyfriend and seek help to improve your relationship.

watch dog training videos or cat behaviour videos to get an understanding of what it means to be 'healthily conditioned'

godspeed

posts.com:
It sounds like you are experiencing a pattern in your relationships where men become quickly obsessed with you, but then lose interest once you begin to reciprocate their feelings. This pattern can be frustrating and confusing, but it may be related to the way you interact with men at the beginning of a relationship.

One possible reason for this pattern is that you may be unconsciously sending mixed signals. By being detached and ignoring men at first, you may be creating a sense of mystery and intrigue that initially draws them to you. However, once you begin to reciprocate their feelings, they may feel that the mystery is gone and lose interest.

Another possibility is that you may be attracting men who are not emotionally mature or ready for a serious relationship. These men may become infatuated quickly, but lack the ability to sustain the interest and commitment over time.

To avoid this pattern, it may be helpful to be more mindful of your behavior and communication in the early stages of a relationship. Try to be more direct and clear about your intentions and feelings, and avoid sending mixed signals. Additionally, it's important to be mindful of the type of men you're attracted to, and make sure they are emotionally mature and ready for a serious relationship.

It's also important to focus on building a strong sense of self-worth and self-confidence, and not relying on the validation of others to feel good about yourself. It's important to be clear about what you want in a relationship and to communicate your needs and boundaries.

It's also important to be patient, and not to rush into a relationship too quickly. Take the time to get to know a person, and be sure that they are the right fit for you before investing too much emotionally.

Ultimately, remember that it's not healthy to base your self-worth on the interest of others, and that you deserve to be with someone who truly values and respects you.

It's natural to become attached to someone when you are getting to know them and building a connection with them. However, it can also be difficult when that attachment doesn't lead to a lasting relationship.

One thing you can do to manage this is to try to avoid getting too invested in a person too quickly. Take your time getting to know someone and try to keep things light and casual in the beginning. This can help you to avoid becoming too attached too soon, and can also give you a chance to see if you are truly compatible with the person.

Another thing you can do is to focus on building a strong sense of self-worth and self-love. When you have a solid sense of self-worth, you are less likely to rely on others for validation and are more likely to be able to detach yourself from a relationship if it doesn't work out.

It's also important to have realistic expectations when it comes to relationships and not to put too much pressure on them. Remember that relationships take time and effort, and it's important to enjoy the process of getting to know someone, rather than focusing too much on the outcome.

It's also important to remember that it's okay to be yourself, and that it's okay to be single. It's important to have a fulfilling life and to not rely solely on a relationship to bring you happiness.

Finally, it's important to remember that it's okay to seek help, and that you don't have to go through this alone. A therapist or counselor can help you work through any feelings of attachment and help you learn how to manage them in a healthy way.

Your time is wasted only if you invest it in a relationship with a low chance of success. Dating involves risk, and not all risks will pan out. Even if this relationship doesn't last, as long as you had genuine cause to believe it could work, it wasn't a waste. It was just an unfortunate result.
It *would* be a waste to prematurely devote yourself to someone, though. Things like paying for his college, living together, having sex, and so on. Basically, acting as if you're committed before you're married will open you up to being taken advantage of, and the devotion that should exclusively be for your spouse is squandered instead on someone who wasn't right for you.

If you think he's the kind of guy to value commitment (and for young men, this is something he should have explicitly talked about, otherwise you should assume greater risk), you trust him to stay faithful while you wait, and your life plans even after graduation are aligned, then it's not a waste to give the relationship a sincere chance. But if you're doubtful about any of these, then it might make sense to break up.

posts.com:
It can be difficult and frustrating to deal with physical limitations, especially when it comes to romantic and intimate activities. It is important to remember that healing and recovery take time, and it's important to be patient with yourself.

Communication with your partner is key, it's important to let your partner know how you feel and to work together to find ways to maintain intimacy and emotional connection during this time. It's also important to find ways to focus on other aspects of your relationship such as emotional intimacy, companionship, and shared activities.

It can also be helpful to seek support from a therapist or counselor who can help you process your feelings and provide strategies for coping with the emotional challenges that you are facing. Additionally, it may be beneficial to explore alternative forms of physical intimacy, such as non-physical touch and emotional connection.

It's also important to take care of yourself physically and emotionally during this time. Make sure to follow your doctor's instructions for recovery and to prioritize self-care activities such as exercise, relaxation techniques, and hobbies that bring you joy.

Blood clot? You mean like the risk of forming a general blood clot?

None of those side effects are common. When medical research is being performed, companies are nominally required to report most of the side effects that are noted by the subjects. So, if you test a drug across 1000 people and 3 of them have a blood clot, it shows up in the documentation as a possible side effect. In reality, those 3 people would have had blood clots anyway, and it's merely coincidence that it occurred at the same time as the testing.

>>28153862
You're right, I don't, that's why it gets listed as a side effect. But this is sort of thing is a great example of correlation =/= causation. There's no proof that the drug directly caused the blood clot, nor that the blood clot would have occurred independently of the drug, and that's why it gets listed as a potential side effect.

But blood clots are a side effect of hundreds of different conditions, lifestyles and environmental factors. In a large sample (which it's fairly safe to assume that the testing groups for a common drug like birth control would be large, probably in the hundreds if not the thousands) you are bound to dig up a number of people with underlying and pre-existing conditions that predispose them to other medical issues that are unrelated to the trial.

In some cases the long list of side effects on drugs is directly related to the demographics of the testing samples. For instance, drugs that are commonly used to treat older people often list side effects that are simply caused by old age, like joint pain. There's no evidence that the drug causes joint pain directly, but your sample is 100 people over the age of 50, so the odds that some of them will experience and report joint pain during the trial is high. And as someone who's been in a drug trial I'll just point out that the trials coordinators WANT you to report any little abnormality. They take your obs regularly, do general checkups and they prompt you to find out if you're experiencing any sort of bodily issues.

I had a similar problem which is a lot better now than it was before. Of course, as with any problem, it comes around every now and then but I'm better at managing it.
What helped me was realizing that the validation I got from others really didn't matter. You cannot please every person you meet or want to be praised by. It is quite literally impossible and a fact of life. It's freeing, really. With that in mind, it is much easier to be yourself. You and I like other people because of their own personal stances, opinions, behaviors. You should do the same. Act the way you personally think is right regardless of what people think. Some people might think you're smart, some may think you're stupid. Either way, you have your own path in life that only you can go through and that other people most likely don't care about.
You can't please everyone so you might as well please yourself. What do YOU like to do? What opinions do YOU have, what dreams, desires, goals? How will YOU decide to invest in them?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28152204
First, you should believe in eternal recurrence, which is the idea that you will live the exact same life over and over again, because if there is any possibility whatsoever that this exact world is recreated again, then it WILL happen. And from your perspective, it will just be the same life, exactly as it is now. So let’s say you were to die right now. Then the only thing recurring would be your life up to this point, which probably isn’t that great, right? But you still have the opportunity to outweigh the past with a good future.

Now, life is inherently meaningful because of our preferences. The starving man doesn’t ask about the “meaning” of eating. He just knows that he wants to eat. But in modern times we are never truly “hungry.” Constant dopamine. That is why you have no drive. Go a day without food and you’ll be hungry. Go a week without fapping and you’ll be horny. Then you’ll remember what it’s like to want to live.

You should embrace suffering, as opposed to the modern idea that suffering is inherently bad and should be reduced at all costs. The most satisfied, accomplished, and life-affirming people suffer more than anyone. It is the people who hate suffering in ALL its forms that want to deny life (see: Buddhists, etc.). So you must cut out the cheap, easy pleasures that we are simply not biologically evolved to handle. Animals live completely meaningful lives, you have to understand this. Human lives are also meaningful. We don’t have to “create” meaning because it’s already there. But people take it away, themselves.

In short: return as best you can to a more natural way of living, cultivating your desire system and making yourself healthy and powerful enough to attain those desires. Embrace the beauty of life with all the good and the bad, and learn to cherish every single second.

I understand that you are going through a difficult and overwhelming situation. It sounds like you are dealing with a lot of stress and responsibilities and it's understandable that you would feel overwhelmed.

It's important to remember that it's okay to reach out for help and support, even if you don't want advice. You can speak with a therapist or counselor, who can provide you with tools and strategies for coping with stress and managing your emotions.

It's also important to seek help from local organizations, such as animal welfare groups, who may be able to provide assistance with the animals on your property, or with the removal of the garbage. They may also be able to help you find resources to help with the costs of animal care.

It's also important to take care of yourself physically and emotionally during this time. Make sure to take time for self-care and relaxation, and try to engage in activities that bring you joy and reduce stress.

It's also important to be honest with yourself and your friends about your situation and how you feel. You don't have to suffer alone and it's important to reach out and connect with people who understand and support you.

Regarding the credit fraud, it's important to know that it is illegal and punishable by law. It's important to seek help and guidance in finding alternative ways to pay your bills, and try to avoid actions that could lead to legal consequences.

Canadian engineering student here,

I am currently in my first year of (general) engineering and I need to select the discipline I want to go into in about a month.

Right now I am debating between computer and mining engineering.

Here are some of my thoughts:

Prospects:
>In Canada, computer engineers (hardware and software) and mining engineers start at about the same salary (~80K CAD) but eventually mining engineers outearn Canadian software and computer hardware engineers by a LOT.
>However, if a Canadian computer engineering grad moves to the US he will outearn Canadian mining engineers by a LOT.
>Canadian computer engineering grads are more likely to move to the US than mining engineering grads as far as I know.
>Canada is a very expensive country. Mining engineers usually live in very low cost of living areas while computer engineers (hardware and software) live in very high cost of living areas.

Work-Life Balance:
>Mining engineers often work for two weeks onsite and then fly home and get two weeks off.
>Mining engineers rarely need to update their skills.
>Computer engineers (hardware and software) work 9-5 every day and get weekends off. They may eventually get the chance to work remotely.
>Computer engineers (software more so than hardware) have to constantly update their skills.

Program:
>Queens (my university) has a global top 10 mining engineering program
>Mining engineering is a lot easier than computer engineering
>Mining engineers get to go on a lot of fun field trips

Skills:
>I enjoy programming but am not an exceptional program. I started programming in my late teens. That being said, I am eager to get better.
>Idk much about mining engineering but I feel like most people going into mining learn the skills they need in university.

(1/2)

Computer Engineering and Mining Engineering are both challenging and rewarding fields of study. They are also quite different from each other and the choice between them will depend on your interests, skills, and career goals.

Computer Engineering involves the design, development, and maintenance of computer systems and networks. It is a broad field that encompasses many different areas such as computer architecture, software engineering, and artificial intelligence. Computer engineers work in a variety of industries including technology, finance, healthcare, and government. They are in high demand and can expect to have many career opportunities with good earning potential.

Mining Engineering, on the other hand, involves the extraction and processing of minerals and metals from the earth. It includes the design, construction, and operation of mines and mineral processing facilities. Mining engineers work in the mining industry, and related industries such as metallurgy, mineral processing, and environmental engineering. They work in a variety of settings, including surface and underground mines, and may be involved in the exploration, development, and reclamation of mining sites.

When considering which program to choose, it's important to think about what interests you and what kind of career you would like to have. It's also important to research the curriculum, opportunities for internships and co-op, and career prospects for each program. Finally, you can speak with current students, professors and professionals in each field to get a better idea of what the field is like and what kind of opportunities are available.

Ultimately, the choice will depend on your interests, skills and career goals. Whichever you choose, both fields are challenging and rewarding and will give you the opportunity to make a meaningful impact in your chosen field.

>You mean "entirely different phenotype"
Race isn't just skin-deep, but if you think relating to the people around you isn't affected by the obvious of looks, you're being purposefully obtuse. There is a reason why self-professed 'anti-racists' love to use language like "making sure POC are SEEN". Because everyone, whether they are honest enough to admit it or not, recognizes that human groups are divided by what they are, not what they act like.
Animal species aren't categorized by temperament. They're categorized by genetics, which phenotype is simply an expression of. And it is these distinct genetic groups which are quite uncontroversially seen as having intrinsic worth, justifying preservation for their own sake. Even distinct subspecies are granted this treatment. And one recognized issue in preserving these distinct groups is hybridization. Suggest the same for humans--that each human group has intrinsic worth, and is worth preserving--and both leftists and miserable stooges like you lose their collective minds.

Lying about your age to your girlfriend can be a difficult situation and it's important to address it as soon as possible. Honesty and trust are important components of any relationship, and lying about your age can undermine the trust that your girlfriend has in you.

The best course of action would be to come clean and tell your girlfriend the truth about your age. It's important to be honest, take responsibility for your actions, and apologize for lying. It's also important to understand that your girlfriend may be hurt and disappointed, so it's important to be prepared for her reaction and be willing to listen and understand her feelings.

It's also important to understand that your girlfriend may have concerns about the age difference and the implications it has on your relationship. Be prepared to address these concerns and assure her that your feelings for her are genuine and that the age difference does not change that.

It's also important to remember that rebuilding trust takes time and effort. Be prepared to demonstrate your honesty and integrity in your actions going forward.

It's worth noting that lying about one's age is a serious matter and it may cause the end of the relationship, it's important to be prepared for that outcome as well.

It's also important to consider why you felt the need to lie about your age in the first place, if it's a deeper issue, such as insecurity or self-esteem, it's worth seeking help from a therapist or counselor to work through those issues.

It can be difficult to confront the reality that we may have become someone that we don't like or respect. However, it's important to remember that it's never too late to make a change and to become the person we want to be.

First, it's important to take a step back and reflect on what led you to become the person you now dislike. What actions or behaviors have you engaged in that you now regret? What values or principles have you compromised? Understanding the reasons behind our actions can help us understand how to change them.

Next, it's important to set clear and specific goals for who you want to become and what changes you want to make. Write down your goals, and make a plan for how you will achieve them.

It's also important to seek help and support from others. Consider talking to a therapist or counselor, who can help you work through your feelings and provide you with strategies for change. Additionally, it's important to surround yourself with people who are positive influences, who will support and encourage you as you work towards becoming the person you want to be.

Finally, it's important to be patient and compassionate with yourself. Change is not easy, and it can take time. Remember that you are not defined by your past actions or the person you used to be. You have the power to change, and you deserve to be the person you want to be.

There is no set amount of money that a person should be making by a certain age, as individual financial situations and goals vary greatly. However, it's generally considered a good idea to have a stable income that can support your basic needs and allow you to save for the future.

It's also important to have a good understanding of budgeting, saving and investing. Having a solid financial plan and sticking to it is more important than achieving a certain income level by a certain age.

It's worth noting that income is not the only factor in achieving financial stability. Building up savings, reducing debt, and investing in assets such as property or stocks can also contribute to financial security.

It's important to set realistic financial goals and make a plan to achieve them. It's also important to remember that your earning potential will change over time and it's more important to focus on building a strong financial foundation and making smart financial decisions.

skin care as a man is pretty easy. I use one of those plastic scrubby things in the shower to exfoliate my skin. Avoid your face, that skin is sensitive.
If you're trying to be "less ugly" the main things you have to focus on are how you dress, what shape is your body in and how will you improve it, and finally- what hair/facial styles will accent my unique features.
For example, I am a very large man. Tall and heavy, got fat recently but still have wider shoulders than hips. I dress to match my body, I show off my figure with tighter clothing but not too tight. My face can work well with long or short hair. It is currently long, so I usually wear a hat or pull the hair back. I have a beard but keep it trimmed to a 2-3 so I don't look homeless.
My style of clothes is a blend of rural denim and flannel but since I have an office job, I also can go business casual very comfortably. It is important to be comfortable in what you're wearing so don't wear clothing that you like, but don't like on you. Better to have three great pairs of pants that you love, and can wear well, than 10 pairs of trendy pants that look like shit on your specifically.
Pic related, this is me. Notice that even though I lost all muscle definition, I did not lose the muscles themselves. I am currently working to regain the definition and have started to re add cardio to my lifts.

Skin care guide for men
>Step 1: Understand your skin type.
Wash your face with clean water, no soap. Wait an hour or so. If your face is dry and flaky, you got dry skin. If the skin feels tight (especially if it feels tight quickly) you have sensitive skin. Sensitive and dry skin often show up as a combo.
If the skin feels oily, you got oily skin.
If its mixed or zone dependent, you got mixed skin, and if nothing much happens at all you have normal / healthy skin.
>Step 2: Buy products where on the label it says your skin type.
You will want the following products:
- a cleanser
- a moisturizer
- a peeling
Men's skin and women's skin are different, so it can make sense to go for men's products, but don't get scammed to buy MAN CREAM that's 4x more expensive than just the regular stuff.
>Step 3: Apply the products. Just follow the package instructions here.
- moisturizer: in the morning and in the evening, daily
- cleanser: in the evening, before applying your moisturizer, daily
- peeling: once per week
>Extra:
- If you go outside or work near a window, always use sunscreen. Your skin will remain young MUCH longer.
- Consider a cream with retinol. However, some people are sensitive to it, so start out without one. Also keeps your skin young.
- There are day & night moisturizers that are a bit different, and you will get slightly better results if you use the day one in the morning and the night one at night.
- Nose strips fuck up your skin, don't use them.
- Those under eye masks against eye bags are good, you may want to use them occasionally.

You can have a balance of both but you need, IMO, a sense of grounded practical direction and which can and should include mundane things. Aimless wandering searching for the final revelation, a new purpose, and new happiness is fraught with disappointment because our lives are first physical and we are biochemical beings who have biochemical needs. The realization of this elevates the physical life to utmost importance before all else. This means your quality of sleep, diet, and exercise should be a “core” of one’s life from which everything else stems — including the big question raised in the OP. Having these in check does a lot to one’s mood and perspective, curbing a lot of aimless wandering and pointless questioning. We are creatures of biological habit and that’s easy to forget in our post-modern, post-scarcity world. I think of it as starting with the basics: why worry about the materials of the roof if the foundation isn’t even built? Everything in its own order rather than a miracle pill, a final epiphany, or a new distraction of the month. If you are healthy fit and in a good mood because your chemical processes are optimized by good habits you may change the definition of will make you happy and content; it could be something simple like a morning walk through nature. The point I’m getting at is that happiness is not something you find, it’s something that’s a byproduct of what you’re doing. The best and easiest way to everyone can achieve success here is to take of their health, exercise, sleep, and eat right.

>>28112537
HPV is incurable, and can sometimes lead to cancer; if you get a strain which causes warts, the individual warts can be treated, but this is painful, and they will keep popping up for several years at least.

HIV is incurable; it is usually treatable, but the drugs are very expensive and can have nasty side effects; you need to take them for life. Occasionally the drugs stop working and people die.

Herpes is incurable, and infects you for life - outbreaks become less frequent with time, but they never stop; herpes simplex 2 is excruciatingly painful; there are drugs that will help treat an outbreak, but you can't take them constantly.

Chlamydia, syphilis and gonorrhoea are usually treatable with antibiotics, but antibiotic-resistant strains of gonorrhoea and syphilis are becoming steadily more common. Note that syphilis can cause insanity or death if it isn't treated, which happens more often than you'd think, because the initial symptoms disappear after a month or two, then it comes back with a vengeance years later, having quietly damaged your central nervous system in the mean time.

Hepatitis is untreatable - you will probably eventually recover from it after several years, but you'll be very sick indeed while you're waiting; it does sometimes kill.

There are other types of bacterial infection that you can pick up from sex; these are generally treatable with antibiotics.
